paddingBottom: Specifies a number of pixels of space between the bottom container boundary and the bottommost edge of the content. Negative numbers are not allowed. Padding is part of an object's width and height. [More information]
paddingLeft: Specifies a number of pixels of space between the left container boundary and the leftmost edge of the content. Negative numbers are not allowed. Padding is part of an object's width and height. [More information]
paddingRight: Specifies a number of pixels of space between the right container boundary and the rightmost edge of the content. Negative numbers are not allowed. Padding is part of an object's width and height. [More information]
paddingTop: Specifies a number of pixels of space between the top container boundary and the topmost edge of the content. Negative numbers are not allowed.Padding is part of an object's width and height. [More information]
pageInclude.onContentLoaded: Event to fire when content has loaded.
pageInclude.onContentLoadFailed: Event to fire when content loading fails.
pageInclude.path: Specifies the relative or absolute URL of the project page file to be used as a Page Include. This lets you use other project page files as components within this file. To specify a file, either type a URL in the field, click the folder to specify a path, or drag a project page file from the Project panel to the field.
pageInclude.reload: Refreshes the project page file within this Page Include.
parseDateTime.day: Returns the day of the month as a number from 1 to 31.
parseDateTime.hour: Returns the hour of the day as a number from 0 to 23.
parseDateTime.input: Specifies the serial number or any supported date time string. [More information]. This can also be text from which a date can be parsed.
parseDateTime.millisecond: Returns the millisecond of the second as a number from 0 to 999.
parseDateTime.minute: Returns the minute of the hour as a number from 0 to 59.
parseDateTime.month: Returns the month of the year as a number from 1 to 12.
parseDateTime.second: Returns the second of the minute as a number from 0 to 59.
parseDateTime.weekday: Returns the day of the week as a number from 1 to 7. The number 1 represents Sunday, and the number 7 represents Saturday.
parseError: Indicates whether the block encountered an error. An error might be caused by improperly formatted input.
parseNumber.input: Specifies the string from which to extract a numeric value.
parseNumber.output: Returns the first numeric value parsed from the input string.
percentOriginX: X position for drawing center point.
percentOriginY: Y position for drawing center point.
percentRadius: Specifies the radius of the circle that Specifies the scale, as a percentage of either half the width or half the height of the container, whichever is larger.
perspective: For 3D−transformed components, specifies how many pixels the component is placed from the view. Note that the child components of the component get the perspective view, not the component itself.
perspectiveOriginX: Specifies where a 3D−transformed component is placed on the X axis.
perspectiveOriginY: Specifies where a 3D−transformed component is placed on the Y axis.
pieSeries.calloutGap: Specifies the amount of empty space, in pixels, that is added to the gap between the edge of the pie and the edge of the labels. Does not define the entire gap, but rather the amount that is added to the default gap. A negative value makes the gap smaller than the default.
pieSeries.calloutStroke: Specifies the stroke color for the wedge callout lines.
pieSeries.calloutStrokeStyle: Specifies the stroke style for the wedge callout lines.
pieSeries.calloutStrokeWidth: Specifies the stroke weight for the wedge callout lines.
pieSeries.colorField:
Specifies the table column that contains data from which to determine wedge colors. The following formats are supported:

  • #EEE — any shortened, three−digit hexadecimal color string, including the # symbol.
  • #FF00FF — any hexadecimal color string, including the # symbol.
  • rgba(255, 0, 0, 0.5) — any RGBA color string, including "rgba" and the parentheses.
Alternatively, you can specify colors in the Property Inspector by expanding Wedge Fills.
pieSeries.dgFills: Specify colors for the pie wedges in this series. Click Add to add a color. To edit a color, click it. Colors are used in order, with the top color corresponding to the top row of table data. The Color Field property overrides this property.
pieSeries.dgWedgeLabel: Configures the text displayed in wedge labels for this series. Use the same tags you would use for a datatip.
pieSeries.explodeRadius: Specifies the distance that the series is exploded, as a percentage of the outer radius of the chart. Wedges move away from the center by this distance without changing their shape.
pieSeries.field: Specifies the table column that contains the pie chart series data that determines wedge size.
pieSeries.innerRadiusInPixels: Returns the inner radius of the pie chart in pixels.
pieSeries.labelPosition:
Specifies the position of the labels.
  • None: No labels.
  • Outside: Labels are positioned for each wedge, near the outer edge of the pie series. Labels might be inside or outside the wedges, depending on the outer radius of the series. < /li>
  • Callout: Labels are positioned outside of the chart, with callout lines. < /li>
  • Inside: Labels are positioned inside each pie wedge. < /li>
  • Inside with Callout: Labels are positioned inside each pie wedge when possible.If a label can 't be positioned inside, it is positioned outside of the chart, with a callout line.
pieSeries.outerRadiusInPixels: Returns the outer radius of the pie chart in pixels.
pieSeries.radialStroke: Specifies the stroke color for the edges between wedges. To edit the inner and outer circles of the pie chart, use the Fill and Stroke properties for the series.
pieSeries.radialStrokeStyle: Specifies the stroke style for the edges between wedges. To edit the inner and outer circles of the pie chart, use the Fill and Stroke properties for the series.
pieSeries.radialStrokeWidth: Specifies the stroke weight for the edges between wedges. To edit the inner and outer circles of the pie chart, use the Fill and Stroke properties for the series.
pieSeries.renderDirection: Specifies the order in which wedges are rendered.
placeholder: Specifies the placeholder text displayed in this input component when there is no input text.
power.input: Specifies the value to be raised to an exponent.
power.output: Returns the result of the calculation.
power.power: Specifies the exponent to be applied to the input value.
preserve3d: When enabled, specifies that child components will preserve their 3D position after the component is transformed.
projectInfo.description: Returns your description of this project. Add a description by selecting Project > Project Properties.
projectInfo.isDesigner:
Returns whether the project is currently open in Edit mode.

TRUE: The project is open in Edit mode.

FALSE: The project is open in Preview mode or the Viewer.
projectInfo.projectId: Returns the automatically−generated unique ID of this project.
projectInfo.superUser: Returns whether the currently logged in user is a Super User.
projectInfo.user: Returns the user that is currently logged in.
projectInfo.version: Returns the version number that you have given to this project. Add a version number by selecting Project > Project Properties.
propertyHub.hubInstance: Binds the master block to child blocks, to enable values to be propagated.
propertyHub.outputAll: Specifies whether complex JSON objects are propagated. For efficiency, such objects are not propagated by default.
propertyHubModifier.0: The name of the property that the field reads and writes.
propertyHubModifier.1: The value of the field, which is read from and written to the property that is specified by field n, according to the hubMode setting.
propertyHubModifier.hubInstance: Binds the master block to child blocks, to enable values to be propagated.
propertyHubModifier.hubMode: Specify the block behavior as follows: Master instantiates the properties object, defines a single master, and binds it to the objects that you want its properties to control. Slave sends and receives values to connected property hubs but does not instantiate the properties. Read-only blocks can have their values set but do not propagate the values, and write-only blocks propagate their values but are not affected by changes to other connected property hubs.

Specify the block behavior as follows: Master instantiates the properties object, defines a single master, and binds it to the objects that you want its properties to control. Slave sends and receives values to connected property hubs but does not instantiate the properties. Read-only blocks can have their values set but do not propagate the values, and write-only blocks propagate their values but are not affected by changes to other connected property hubs.
queryBinding.0: A data mapping compares a binding's source value to one or more Case values in order, until the statement it is evaluating is TRUE:. For numbers, a data mapping checks whether the source value is less than or equal to the Case value. For other data types, the data mapping checks whether the source value is equal to the Case value. When the first TRUE statement is encountered, that Mapping value is assigned to the binding's target. If none of the statements are TRUE, then the default value is assigned to the binding's target. More complex case mappings can be created in the dataflow using the Case block.
queryBinding.default: A value to assign to the target if none of the expressions are TRUE.
queryBinding.scaleInputMax: The upper bound of the original scale. A scale binding takes the source value's relationship to an original scale and returns the corresponding value on a new scale. (More information)
queryBinding.scaleInputMin: The lower bound of the original scale. A scale binding takes the source value's relationship to an original scale and returns the corresponding value on a new scale. (More information)
queryBinding.scaleOutputMax: The upper bound of the new scale. A scale binding takes the source value's relationship to an original scale and returns the corresponding value on a new scale. (More information)
queryBinding.scaleOutputMin: The lower bound of the new scale. A scale binding takes the source value's relationship to an original scale and returns the corresponding value on a new scale. (More information)
radius: For standard markers, specifies the marker radius in pixels. For custom markers, specifies the largest radius of an inscribed ellipse, in pixels. This property is equal to half the symbol width or half the symbol height, whichever is larger.
rangeFormInput.alwaysShowSpinner: By default, spinners are displayed only when the user mouses over an input field. To always display spinners, set the property to TRUE.
rangeFormInput.ticks: Specifies values where ticks appear on the range selector, as a list of comma−separated values.
rawSvgRepeater.borderOffset: Specifies the distance into the dash pattern to start the dash.
rawSvgRepeater.borderPattern: Specifies the pattern of dashes and gaps used to be used, specified as a comma−separated list of lengths.
rawSvgRepeater.data: Specifies the table that controls the SVG repeater. The SVG component repeats once for each row in the table. Table columns can be used to represent attributes of the SVG component, such as style or coordinates.
rawSvgRepeater.dataTipSymbol: Specifies the symbol that appears as a datatip when mousing over an instance of the SVG in this repeater.
rawSvgRepeater.svgDefs:
Specifies the <defs> component for the repeated SVG component. The following example specifies a style for the repeated SVG rectangle. The style includes a green fill and a black border stroke.

Example: <style>rect{fill:green;stroke:black;}</style>
realtimeRecorder.0: Specifies a column name for the value n values in the output table.
realtimeRecorder.1: Specifies a value to monitor and output in the output table.
realtimeRecorder.bufferSize: Specifies the number of rows that the output table can hold. When the buffer is full, the oldest rows are deleted from memory.
realtimeRecorder.enabled: Determines whether the block is currently recording and creating a table.
realtimeRecorder.ignoreNullValue: To ignore null values, set to TRUE.
realtimeRecorder.output: Returns a table of timestamps and values. The table contains a row for each monitored change.
relativize.output: An instance of the relativizing service. Click the button to interact with the service. For details, watch the video Introduction to Relativization.
relativize.path: Sets and returns the current parent directory containing the relative paths.
rendererHeight: Specify height for virtual layout for a group repeater.
rendererWidth: Specify width for virtual layout for a group repeater.
repeater.data: Specifies the table that determines the number of symbol instances and the properties of each symbol instance.
repeater.output: Returns a table that lists the symbol parameter values for each instance of the symbol.
repeater.renderer: The renderer to be used for the repeater.
repeater.streamQueue: Size of the queue for a repeater in stream mode.
repeater.symbol: Specifies the name of the dataflow symbol to repeat.
repeater.thread: Specifies the number of renderers created for the repeater in threaded mode or stream mode.
replace.1: Specifies the text to replace find n with.
replace.input: Specifies the text string in which to replace characters.
replace.output: Returns the string with all replacements.
replace.regexp: Specifies whether to use a regular expression to find strings.
resizeEventData.active: Specifies whether the listener is currently listening.
resizeEventData.clientHeight: Returns the height of the contents of this component, in pixels, when the component is resized. It includes padding, but it does not include the border or horizontal scroll bar.
resizeEventData.clientWidth: Returns the width of the contents of this component, in pixels, when the component is resized. It includes padding, but it does not include the border or vertical scroll bar.
resizeEventData.event: Fires when the input event occurs and displays the name of the event type. It can be bound to an event.
resizeEventData.input: Specifies the event type to listen for. By default, it is the onResize event for this component.
resizeEventData.offsetHeight: Returns the height of this entire component, in pixels, when the component is resized.
resizeEventData.offsetWidth: Returns the width of this entire component, in pixels, when the component is resized.
resizeEventEnabled: When TRUE, permits the 'resize' event to be triggered for the component.
reverseZIndex: For containers with horizontal or vertical layout that contain overlapping components, reverses the overlapped components.
right: In an absolute layout, sets the right edge of this component to a distance to the left or right of the right edge of its parent container. In a vertical or horizontal layout, sets the right edge of this component to a distance to the left or right of its normal position. Distances are specified in pixels or as a percentages of the parent width. A value of Auto positions the right edge of this component in its normal position. To set a value of Auto, click the blue dot and select Reset.
right.input: Specifies the text string that contains the characters to extract.
right.length: Specifies how many characters to extract.
root.input: Specifies the value to take the root of.
root.output: Returns the result of the calculation.
root.root: Specifies the root to use. For example, a value of 3 calculates a cubic root.
rotate: Specifies a 2D rotation. The value is an angle in degrees.
rotateX: Specifies a 3D rotation along the x−axis. The value is an angle in degrees.
rotateY: Specifies a 3D rotation along the y−axis. The value is an angle in degrees.
round.input: Specifies any real number that you want to round.
round.minPrecision: The minimum number of decimal digits to be returned.
round.precision: Specifies the number of digits after the decimal to round the number to. A value of 0, less than 0, or null rounds the number to the nearest integer.
roundDown.input: Specifies the real number that is to be rounded down.
roundDown.precision: Specifies the number of digits after the decimal to round the number to. A value of 0, less than 0, or null rounds the number down to the nearest integer.
roundedCornersEditable: Do not change. For internal use.
roundUp.input: Specifies the real number that is to be rounded up.
roundUp.precision: Specifies the number of digits after the decimal to round the number to. A value of 0, less than 0, or null rounds the number up to the nearest integer.
router.0: Specifies a test value that is to be compared with the incoming value.
router.1: Specifies the value that is output if the condition evaluates to TRUE.
router.case: Specifies the incoming value that is to be compared with each test value.
router.condition: Specifies the incoming value that is to be compared with each test value.
router.else: Specifies the value to be output if none of the conditions are met. (More information)
router.event: Specifies the event that triggers the block. You can bind only a single event to a Router block. If you want several different types of events to trigger the same Router block, use a Hub block to coalesce the events to a single output event.
router.op: Specifies the operator to be used to evaluate the condition.
router.output: Specifies the value that is output if the condition evaluates to TRUE.
router.singleOutput: When singleOutput is set to TRUE, all outputs but the result are set to null when an event is routed. By default, outputs retain their value between evaluations.
saDir: Specifies the direction toward which the series slides. For example, if this property is set to Left, the series slides onto the chart from right to left.
saDurationEx.duration: Specifies the duration of the animation in seconds. The Element Offset and Minimum component Duration properties can cause the animation duration to be longer than that specified by the Duration property.
saElOffset:
Specifies the amount of time, in seconds, that the animation of each component in the series is delayed. A value of zero means that all components in the series begin animating at the same time and finish at the same time. A value of 1 means that the second component starts and finishes animating one second after the first component, and so on.

The Element Offset and Minimum component Duration properties can cause the animation duration to be longer than that specified by the Duration property.
saHFocus:
Together with Vertical Focus and Relative To, determines the focal point of the zoom animation.
  • Left: The zoom animation begins at the left of the bounding box defined in Relative To.
  • Right: The zoom animation begins at the right of the bounding box defined in Relative To.
  • Center: The zoom animation begins at the horizontal center of the bounding box defined in Relative To.
  • Null: If Horizontal Focus is null, and Vertical Focus is not null, then the focus is a horizontal line rather than a point. If both values are null, then the focal point is the center of the bounding box.
saMinElDuration: Specifies the minimum amount of time, in seconds, that an individual component takes to complete the animation. The Element Offset and Minimum component Duration properties can cause the animation duration to be longer than that specified by the Duration property.
saOffset: Specifies the amount of time, in seconds, that the animation is delayed. Use this property to stagger effects on multiple series.
saRelTo:
Controls the bounding box used to determine the focal point of the zoom animation. Used together with Horizontal Focus and Vertical Focus.

Series: The bounding box tightly surrounds the horizontal and vertical minimums and maximums of the series data.

Chart: The bounding box tightly surrounds the plot area of the chart.
saType:
Specifies animation behavior for this series.

  • None: An updated chart replaces the old chart without any animation.
  • Interpolate: The series goes through a smooth transition, with the old chart as the first frame and the new chart as the final frame.
  • Slide: The series "slides" in and out of the chart boundaries from a direction that you specify.
  • Zoom: The series "implodes" and "explodes" from a focal point that you specify.
saVFocus:
Together with Horizontal Focus and Relative To, determines the focal point of the zoom animation.
  • Top: The zoom animation begins at the top of the bounding box defined in Relative To.
  • Bottom: The zoom animation begins at the bottom of the bounding box defined in Relative To.
  • Center: The zoom animation begins at the vertical center of the bounding box defined in Relative To.
  • Null: If Vertical Focus is null, and Horizontal Focus is not null, then the focus is a vertical line rather than a point. If both values are null, then the focal point is the center of the bounding box.
scale.inputMax: Specifies the maximum of the original scale.
scale.inputMin: Specifies the minimum of the original scale.
scale.inputOutOfRange: Returns TRUE if the input is outside the range, FALSE otherwise.
scale.output: Returns the value in the new scale that corresponds to input in the old scale. If input is below the input range, output returns outputMin. If input is above the input range, output returns outputMax.
scale.outputMax: Specifies the maximum of the new scale.
scale.outputMin: Specifies the minimum of the new scale.
scaleContent:
Specifies the scaling behavior of children of this group when the group size changes. Only works when group layout is absolute.

  • None: Children do not scale when group size changes.
  • Fit ratio: Children scale while maintaining their aspect ratios.
  • Fit: Children scale without maintaining their aspect ratios.
scaleLabels.formatString:
Specifies the number format for scale labels, as a format string. [More information] For example:

  • ,##0.00 — Labels have a thousands separator and two decimal digits. < /li>
  • 000.00 & mdash;Labels have three mandatory digits before the decimal and two mandatory digits after the decimal. < /li>
scaleLabels.justify: Specifies whether the labels appear on the inside, outside, or center of the circle or line that Specifies the scale.
scaleLabels.labelsFontFamily:
Specifies the font used for the labels along this scale. To add a font to your project:
  1. If your project does not have a fonts folder, right−click the root folder for your project, and add a folder named fonts
  2. Navigate to the font file on your computer and drag it to the fonts folder.
  3. Save your work and refresh the browser.
  4. Specify the font using the drop−down menu for this property.
scaleLabels.majorTicksCount: Specifies the total number of labels along a labeled scale. Must be an integer greater than or equal to 2. The Only Min/Max Labels property overrides this property.
scaleLabels.percentTextSize: Specifies the height of the scale labels, as a pixel value or percentage. For circular scales, a percentage is a portion of the circle's radius. For linear scales, a percentage is a portion of half the container width.
scaleLabels.showMinMaxOnly: Specifies whether the labels for the minimum and maximum of the scale are the only two labels that appear. This property overrides the Labels Count property.
scaleTicks.majorTicksCount: Specifies the total number of major ticks along this scale.
scaleTicks.majorTicksPercentLength: Specifies the length of each major tick, as a pixel value or a percentage. For circular scales, a percentage is a portion of the circle's radius. For linear scales, a percentage is a portion of half the container width.
scaleTicks.majorTickStroke: Specifies the stroke color of the major ticks.
scaleTicks.majorTickStrokeWidth: Specifies the stroke weight of each major tick.
scaleTicks.minorTicksCount: Specifies the number of minor ticks between each consecutive pair of major ticks.
scaleTicks.minorTicksPercentLength: Specifies the length of each minor tick, as a pixel value or a percentage. For circular scales, a percentage is a portion of the circle's radius. For linear scales, a percentage is a portion of half the container width.
scaleTicks.ticksPlacement: Specifies whether the ticks are positioned on the inside, outside, or center of the circle or line that Specifies the scale.
scaleTrack.percentEndThickness: Specifies the thickness of the scale track at its end, as a pixel or percentage value. For circular scales, a percentage is a portion of the circle's radius. For linear scales, a percentage is a portion of the entire container width.
scaleTrack.percentStartThickness: Specifies the thickness of the scale track at its start, as a pixel or percentage value. For circular scales, a percentage is a portion of the circle's radius. For linear scales, a percentage is a portion of the entire container width.
scaleTrack.placement: Specifies whether the track is positioned on the inside, outside, or center of the circle or line that Specifies the scale.
scaleType: Specifies whether the shape of the scale is defined by a circle or a straight line.
scaleX: Specifies a 3D scale transformation by giving a value for the X−axis
scaleY: Specifies a 3D scale transformation by giving a value for the Y−axis
script.a: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.autoRun:
Specifies whether the script runs automatically.

TRUE
The script runs every time the script is changed, and every time any property is changed. This includes the first time that the script is initialized.

FALSE
The script runs only when the invoke property is triggered.
script.b: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.c: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.d: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.e: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.f: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.g: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.i: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.j: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.k: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.l: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.m: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.n: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.o: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.output: Returns the output of your script.
script.p: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.print: Returns a string that is used for errors, other notifications, and debugging. (More information)
script.q: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.qosMode:
Specifies whether the script runs as soon as it's invoked.

FALSE
The script waits for other blocks in the queue to finish their logic before it runs, no matter how many times the script is triggered before it's run, it will only run once.

TRUE
The script runs instantly when script is invoked, and it won't wait for other blocks in the queue to finish their logic. This allows the script to handle every invoke and never skip data update.

Besides invoke, if there are other bindings to the script block, they might not always be updated by the time script is run

When the output of a streaming mode repeater is bound to the script's invoke, the script's qosMode needs to be TRUE, otherwise it might lose the update comes from repeater.
script.r: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.s: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.script: Specifies the instance of DGScript held by this block. See Scripting and Syntax for more information about creating a script.
script.t: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.u: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.v: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.w: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.x: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.y: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
script.z: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
scrollbarStyles.height: Specifies the height of the horizontal scrollbar on this container, as a pixel value or a percentage of the container height.
scrollbarStyles.thumb.background: Specifies the fill of the thumbs in this container's scrollbars.
scrollbarStyles.thumb.border: Specifies the stroke color for outlining the thumbs in this container's scrollbars.
scrollbarStyles.thumb.borderStyle: Specifies the stroke style for outlining the thumbs in this container's scrollbars.
scrollbarStyles.thumb.borderWidth: Specifies the stroke weight for outlining the thumbs in this container's scrollbars.
scrollbarStyles.thumb.cornerRadius: Specifies rounded corners for the thumbs in this container's scrollbars, as arcs of circles or ellipses. The circles or ellipses are defined using a pixel value or percentage. A pixel value Specifies the radius of a circle. A percentage value Specifies an ellipse with horizontal and vertical radii that are that percentage of the component's width and height, respectively.
scrollbarStyles.track.background: Specifies the fill of the track in this container's scrollbars.
scrollbarStyles.track.border: Specifies the stroke color for outlining the track in this container's scrollbars.
scrollbarStyles.track.borderStyle: Specifies the stroke style for outlining the track in this container's scrollbars.
scrollbarStyles.track.borderWidth: Specifies the stroke weight for outlining the track in this container's scrollbars.
scrollbarStyles.track.cornerRadius: Specifies rounded corners for the tracks in this container's scrollbars, as arcs of circles or ellipses. The circles or ellipses are defined using a pixel value or percentage. A pixel value Specifies the radius of a circle. A percentage value Specifies an ellipse with horizontal and vertical radii that are that percentage of the component's width and height, respectively.
scrollbarStyles.width: Specifies the width of the vertical scrollbar on this container, as a pixel value or a percentage of the container width.
scrollEventData.active:
Determines whether the block is currently listening.

TRUE: The output properties of the block update whenever the user scrolls.

FALSE: The output properties of the block do not update.
scrollEventData.event: Returns the type of event that triggered this block.
scrollEventData.input: Specifies the event on which the scroll listener starts reporting data. By default, input is an instance of onScrollEvent, so the listener returns data whenever the parent is scrolled. Note that the onScrollEvent property does not exist for all component types.
scrollEventData.scrollLeft: Returns the difference in pixels between the left edge of the content and the left edge of the portion currently scrolled to.
scrollEventData.scrollTop: Returns the difference in pixels between the top edge of the content and the top edge of the portion currently scrolled to.
scrollFastResponse: To make synchronized scrolling smooth, update the position data immediately when it changes.
scrollFeedback: Set to TRUE to enable the scrollX and scrollY properties to be populated when the user scrolls.
scrollX: For a scrollable component, the number of pixels that the component is currently scrolled horizontally. This property is populated when the scrollFeedback property is enabled.
scrollY: For a scrollable component, the number of pixels that the component is currently scrolled vertically. This property is populated when the scrollFeedback property is enabled.
selectChildOnClick: When enabled, users can select child components by clicking them.
selected:
A runtime property that shows whether this component is selected. This property is not saved in Edit mode.

This property is related to the parent's Selection Behavior property. For example, if the Selection Behavior of this component's parent is Single Select, then clicking this component selects it and deselects its siblings. For more about the Selection Behavior property, see the wiki.

Regardless of the parent's Selection Behavior, you can also change this property in the Property Inspector. For example, if you want this component to be selected when the user clicks a menu button, bind the Selected property of the button to the Selected property of this component.
selectedBackground: Specifies the fill for selected cells.
selectedBorder: Specifies the stroke color or border image for outlining selected cells.
selectedCornerRadius: Specifies the corner radius for selected cells, as arcs of circles or ellipses.  The circles or ellipses are defined using a pixel value or percentage. A pixel value is the radius of a circle. A percentage value Specifies an ellipse with horizontal and vertical radii that are that percentage of the cell's width and height, respectively. A value of 0 means that corners are not rounded.
selectedFontColor: Specifies the font color for numbers in selected cells.
selectedFontFamily:
Specifies the font for numbers in selected cells. To add a font to your project:
  1. If your project does not have a fonts folder, right−click the root folder for your project, and add a folder named fonts.
  2. Navigate to the font file on your computer and drag it to the fonts folder.
  3. Save your work and refresh the browser.
  4. Specify the font using the drop−down menu for this property.
selectedFontSize: Specifies the font size for numbers in selected cells.
selectedFontStyle: Specifies whether the text in selected cells is italic.
selectedFontWeight: Specifies whether the text in selected cells is bold.
selectedIndex: Sets or returns the index of the selected item in this container. An index of 0 indicates the first item. An index of −1 deselects all items. If Multi−Select is enabled and multiple items are selected, comma−separated values are used.
selectedStyle: For internal use, do not change.
selectedValue: For use with repeaters. If the keyColumn property is set, this property is populated with the values from the specified column. For a multiple selection, selectedValue is populated with a comma−separated list of values.
selectOnEnter: When enabled, users can select by hitting the Enter key.
seriesRealtimeRecorder.0: value n specifies a value in the output table, and name n specifies a name for the value.
seriesRealtimeRecorder.enabled: Determines whether the block is currently recording and updating the table.
seriesRealtimeRecorder.output: Returns a table of names and values.
seriesType:
Specifies how the series data is visually represented.

  • Line series: Markers represent the data points. Lines connect the markers.
  • Area series: Markers represent the data points. Lines connect the markers, and the area delimited by the lines is filled in.
  • Bar series: Horizontal bars represent the data points.
  • Column series: Vertical columns represent the data points.
service: Service from which to get data.
shadows: Attaches one or more shadows to this component.
shear: Specifies the angle for a 3D shear transformation.
showDataTips: Specifies whether datatips are displayed when the user mouses over data points. If this series uses custom markers, datatips are shown by default.
showDay: Specifies whether this date range picker includes an option to choose a day.
showFullTime:
Specifies whether the Range portion of the date range picker includes time.

TRUE: The date range picker can specify start and end times and dates.

FALSE: The date range picker can specify start and end dates only.
showLabels: Specifies whether this series has labels.
showMonth: Specifies whether this date range picker includes an option to choose a calendar month.
showRange: Specifies whether this date range picker includes an option to choose a starting date/time and ending date/time.
showRelative: Specifies whether this date range picker includes an option to choose a date range relative to the current date.
showWeek: Specifies whether this date range picker includes an option to choose a week beginning on Sunday and ending on Saturday.
showYear: Specifies whether this date range picker includes an option to choose a calendar year.
sin.input: Specifies the angle to get the sine for, in degrees.
sin.output: Returns the sine of the input.
spectrumSeries.dateField: Specifies the name of the column from which to read dates.
spectrumSeries.highSeparatorColor: Color that is used for value between middle and maximum.
spectrumSeries.lowSeparatorColor: Color that is used for value between middle and minimum.
spectrumSeries.roundTime:
Specifies whether to force all intervals to start at a round number.

TRUE: Intervals start at a round number. For example, if interval is "day", all intervals start at midnight. If interval is "five minutes", all intervals start at multiples of five minutes past the hour.

FALSE: The first interval starts at the first timestamp, and intervals are appended accordingly. For example, if interval is "day" and the first value is 2015/07/19T08:01:19, then all intervals begin at T08:01:19.
spectrumSeries.valueField: Specifies the name of the column from which to read values.
spectrumSeries.valueRollup:
Specifies the type of rollup used.
  • First: Returns the first value for the interval.
  • Last: Returns the last value for the interval.
  • Average: Returns the average of all number values for the interval. Non−number values are treated as null and are not included in the calculation.
  • Sum: Returns the sum of all number values for the interval. If there are no number values, returns 0.
  • Max: Returns the greatest number value from the interval. If there are no number values, returns null.
  • Min: Returns the smallest number value for the interval. Non−number values are treated as null and are not included in the calculation.
  • Count: Returns the number of values that exist for the interval. Null values are not included.
  • Concat: Returns all values for the interval, separated by commas. Duplicate values are included.
  • ConcatUnique: Returns all unique values for the interval, separated by commas. Duplicate values are not included.
spellcheck: Enable or disable spell checking for the component.
split.input: Specifies the string to separate into pieces.
split.output: Returns a table that contains the pieces of the input string as rows.
split.separator: Specifies the character or string that delimits the pieces.
stdDeviation.0: Specifies one of the numbers in the sample.
stdDeviation.output: Returns the standard deviation of the input values.
step: Specifies the interval between valid numbers for this input component. Valid numbers are the minimum and multiples of the Step value larger than the minimum. If no minimum is defined, valid numbers are zero and multiples of the Step value larger or smaller than zero. A Step value of zero means that any interval is allowed.
stopwatch.enabled: Sets or returns whether the stopwatch is currently running.
stopwatch.interval: Specifies the duration, in seconds, between stopwatch updates. For example, if interval is 0.5 seconds, the stopwatch counts up every 0.5 seconds.
stopwatch.loop:
Determines whether the stopwatch resets in a loop, based on the modulo value.

TRUE: The stopwatch resets when its output reaches the final step before reaching modulo. If the difference between the final step and modulo equals the step value, the stopwatch restarts at 0. If the difference is less than the step value, the stopwatch restarts with a value of that difference.

FALSE: The stopwatch stops counting when it reaches the final step where output is less than or equal to modulo.
stopwatch.modulo: specifies the value that signals the stopwatch to stop or reset. If loop is TRUE, then the output value is always less than modulo. If loop is FALSE, then the output value is always equal to or less than modulo.
stopwatch.onLoop: Fires when the stopwatch either loops or stops. It can be used to trigger an action.
stopwatch.reset: Causes the stopwatch to restart at 0 (default) or the value specified in the resetValue property. (More information)
stopwatch.resetValue: The value to which the stopwatch is set when reset is triggered (default is 0).
stopwatch.step: Specifies the number that is added to the output with each update. For example, if step is 1, then each time the stopwatch updates, its output increases by 1.
strength: Affects the differential or the change rate of the easing function. A value of 0.5 is the default. Values below 0.5 decrease the differential or the change rate, making the easing appear less pronounced. Values above 0.5 increase the differential or the change rate, making the easing appear more pronounced.
strengthBack: Affects the differential or the change rate of the easing function in the reverse manner of the Strength property. See Strength for details.
string.value: Sets and returns the value of this String block.
strLoader.autoRun:
Specifies whether the string is loaded automatically.

TRUE
The string is loaded every time any property is changed. This includes the first time that the path property is populated.

FALSE
The string is loaded only when the invoke property is triggered, or at the specified interval.
strLoader.data: Sets and returns either the payload for a POST request, or the string to be added to the URL for a GET request.
strLoader.enabled:
Specifies whether the string loader is enabled.

FALSE: The string does not load.

TRUE: The string loads as specified by invoke, autoRun, and interval.
strLoader.errorGroup: For error handling with catchError blocks, specifies the group for errors that occur when executing this block.
strLoader.headers: Sets the headers for the HTTP request. Use the following syntax: abc=abc&def=def
strLoader.interval: Specifies how often the string is reloaded automatically, in seconds. A value of 0 means that the string is reloaded on autoRun or invoke only.
strLoader.invoke: Causes the string to be loaded. Only works if enabled is set to TRUE.
strLoader.loading: Returns TRUE if the string is currently being loaded.
strLoader.method:
Specifies the HTTP request method for loading the string. In almost all cases, you want GET or POST.

GET: Retrieves the string at the specified URL.

POST: Adds something to the string at the specified URL.
strLoader.onComplete: Fires when the string finishes loading.
strLoader.output: Returns the string contained in the file. Link this property to the input of a Parser block to create a table.
strLoader.path: Specifies the URL to load the string from. It can be a file path relative to the current project root or a URL.
strLoader.respHeaders: Returns the HTTP response headers received when the string is loaded.
strLoader.sendCookies: Specifies whether to send the user's cookie to the URL from which you are retrieving the string. It is safer not to send cookies, but you must send cookies to get certain custom information, such as a particular user's Twitter feed.
strLoader.timeout: Specifies how long the block attempts to load the string before the request is canceled.
stroke: Specifies the stroke for this component.
strokeStyle: Specifies the stroke style for outlining this component.
strokeWidth: Specifies the stroke weight or border width for outlining this component.
strUploader.data: Holds the string that becomes the contents of this file.
strUploader.deleteEmptyFile:
Specifies whether to delete the file if data is null.

TRUE: If data is null, nothing is uploaded to the server. If a file with the specified path already exists on the server, that file is deleted.

FALSE: Even if data is null, a file is created when this block is invoked. The file is blank.
strUploader.enabled:
Specifies whether the string uploader is enabled.

TRUE: A file containing the string is uploaded when this block is invoked.

FALSE: Nothing happens when this block is invoked.
strUploader.invoke: Causes the new file to be created. Only works if enabled is set to TRUE.
strUploader.onComplete: Fires when the file has been created.
strUploader.path:
Specifies where to upload the new file, relative to the root of this project. Must include a file name and extension.

  • To save to the root, enter /<filename>.<extension>.
  • To save to the assets folder, enter assets/<filename>.<extension>
subscribeValue.enabled:
Specifies whether this block updates when the value is updated.

TRUE: This block retrieves the value when the value changes.

FALSE: This block does nothing, even when the value changes.
subscribeValue.lastUpdate: Returns the date and time of the most recently loaded value.
subscribeValue.path: Specifies the absolute location of the node.
substring.end: Determines the position of the last character to extract.
substring.input: Specifies the text string that contains the characters to extract.
substring.length: Specifies the number of characters to extract.
substring.start: Determines the position of the first character to extract from the input text. A value of 0 indicates the first character in the input. (More information)
subtract.0: Specifies one of the numbers to subtract. Subtraction is calculated in order, top to bottom.
subtract.output: Returns the result of subtracting the input values.
svg:text.textAnchor: Specifies how text is aligned to the SVG component.
svgId: For internal use. Do not change.
svgLightElement.azimuth: The direction angle for the light source on the XY plane (clockwise), in degrees from the x axis.
svgLightElement.elevation: The direction angle for the light source from the XY plane towards the z axis, specified in degrees. Note that the positive z axis points towards the viewer of the content.
svgLightElement.limitingConeAngle: The angle in degrees between the spot light axis (the axis between the light source and the point to which it is pointing at) and the spot light cone. It defines a limiting cone that restricts the region where the light is projected. No light is projected outside the cone.
svgLightElement.specularExponent: Exponent for specular term, range 1.0 to 128.0. The higher the setting, the shiner the result.
symbol: Path for the symbol to use as item renderer in repeater mode.
symbol.symbol: Specifies which symbol is displayed in this symbol component. To use a symbol that is defined in the currently-open project, enter the name of the symbol. To use a symbol from another project in your library, enter the path to that symbol. By default, this is the only property for a symbol. To add properties to a symbol, open the Edit Properties dialog for that symbol.
table: Table to be used as data source
table.data: Sets and returns the value of this Table block formatted as a table.
table.save: Removes any binding to the data property. When save is invoked, data currently in the table is maintained.
tableAddRow.0: Specifies the name of a column in the input table.
tableAddRow.1: Specifies the value to insert in column n in the new row.
tableAddRow.enabled:
Determines whether the block is enabled.

TRUE: The row is added when the trigger is invoked.

FALSE: The row is not added.
tableAddRow.invoke: Causes the row to be added.
tableAddRow.table: Specifies the input table that will receive the added row.
tableAggregation.column: Specifies the name of the table column.
tableAggregation.input: Receives the table in which you want to aggregate values.
tableAggregation.method:
Specifies the type of aggregation. (More information)
  • First: Returns the first value in the column.
  • Last: Returns the last value in the column.
  • Average: Returns the average of all number values in the column. Non−number values are treated as null and are not included in the calculation.
  • Sum: Returns the sum of all number values in the column. If there are no number values, returns 0.
  • Max: Returns the greatest number value in the column. If there are no number values, returns null.
  • Min: Returns the smallest number value in the column. Non−number values are treated as null and are not included in the calculation.
  • Count: Returns the number of values in the column. Null values are not included.
  • Concat: Returns all values in the column, separated by commas. Duplicate values are included.
  • Concat unique: Returns all unique values in the column, separated by commas. Duplicate values are not included.
  • Table Union: If the data type of the input column is "table", performs a union join on the nested tables and returns the joined table.
tableAggregation.output: Returns the output determined by the method property.
tableColumnMapping.0:
name n specifies the new column name. from n specifies the data to appear in the new column, using JavaScript notation. For example:
  • "=v1+v2" returns the sum of the values in the "v1" column and the "v2" column.
  • "=dateFormat(timestamp,"y−MM−dd")" returns the date in the "timestamp" column with the specified formatting.
  • "=numberFormat(value,"0.00")" returns the value in the "value" column, rounded to the hundredths place.
See Column Mapping
tableColumnMapping.output: Returns the output table with new columns.
tableColumnMapping.print: Displays error messages and other notifications for debugging.
tableColumnMapping.retainColumns: Specifies whether to include the input table's columns in the output table.
tableEditRows.0: Specifies the name of a column in the input table.
tableEditRows.1: Specifies the value to insert in column n in the input table.
tableEditRows.condition: Specifies the expression that determines which rows are to be edited. For example, to edit the first row in the table, enter row==0. See Scripting and Syntax.
tableEditRows.enabled:
Determines whether the block is enabled.

TRUE: The values are replaced when the trigger is invoked.

FALSE: The values are not replaced.
tableEditRows.invoke: Causes the values to be replaced.
tableEditRows.print: Returns a string that is used for errors, other notifications, and debugging
tableEditRows.table: Receives the input table in which some values will be replaced.
tableFilter.condition: Specifies the condition of the filter. Use Javascript notation. For example, "Damper_Pos==0" returns all rows where the value of the "Damper_Pos" column is 0.
tableFilter.input: Receives the table that you want to filter.
tableFilter.print: Returns output from the condition field. Use it for debugging.
tableGetColumns.input: Receives the table from which you want to get column names and data types.
tableGetColumns.output: Returns the output table. It contains a row for each column in the input table.
tableGroupBy.0: Specifies the name of an input table column to group.
tableGroupBy.1:
specifies how to return values in column n for each baseColumn value.

first: Returns the first value in the group.

last: Returns the last value in the group.

average: Returns the average of all number values in the group. Non−number values are treated as null and are not included in the calculation.

sum: Returns the sum of all number values in the group. If there are no number values, returns 0.

max: Returns the largest number value in the group. If there are no number values, returns null.

min: Returns the smallest number in the group. Non−number values are treated as null and are not included in the calculation.

count: Returns the number of values in the group.

concat: Returns all values in the group, separated by commas. Duplicate values are listed.

concatUnique: Returns all unique values in the group, separated by commas. Duplicate values are not listed.

tableUnion: Returns a table of values.
tableGroupBy.2: Specifies the label for the column of grouped column n values.
tableGroupBy.baseColumn: Specifies the name of the table column in which to group values.
tableGroupBy.includeBlankValue: Specifies whether to include a row for a blank value of baseColumn, if a blank value exists.
tableGroupBy.input: Receives the table whose values you want to group.
tableGroupBy.nestedData: Specifies whether to keep the original rows in a new column of the output table as nested tables. For more information about nested tables, see How do I view the data in nested tables?
tableGroupBy.output: Returns the output table. It contains one row for each unique value in baseColumn.
tableJoin.field1: Specifies the name of the key column from the input1 table.
tableJoin.field2: Specifies the name of the key column from the input2 table.
tableJoin.input1: Specifies the left table for the join operation.
tableJoin.input2: Specifies the right table for the join operation.
tableJoin.join:
Determines the method of joining.The value of the join property can be one of the following:

Left: All rows from input1 are included. Rows from input2 are included and merged when the column2 value matches a column1 value.

Right: All rows from input2 are included. Rows from input1 are included and merged when the column1 value matches a column2 value.

Inner: Rows are included and merged only when the values in column1 and column2 are the same.

Full: All rows from both tables are included, and the rows are merged if the values of column1 and column2 are the same.

Union: All rows from both tables are included in a new table. Rows are not merged.
tableJoin.renameColumns:
Determines the names in the output table for columns that come from input2. Make sure to rename columns if you don't want them combined. Use this syntax:

column1:newName
column2:newName

Press Alt + Enter to create line breaks between columns. To edit text in a popup window, click the Edit in Window icon.
tableMultiJoin.0: Specifies a source table for the join.
tableMultiJoin.1: Comma-separated list of columns to be omitted from the join.
tableMultiJoin.column: Column on which the join is performed.
tablePage.currentPage: Sets or returns the current page.
tablePage.firstPage: Changes the output table to the first page.
tablePage.input: Receives the table for which you want to create paging.
tablePage.lastPage: Advances the output table to the last page.
tablePage.nextPage: Advances the output table to the next page.
tablePage.output: Returns the portion of the input table specified by the paging parameters.
tablePage.pageSize: Specifies the number of rows per page.
tablePage.prevPage: Changes the output table to the previous page.
tablePage.start: Specifies the row index on which to start the current page. Rows before this index are omitted from the output. (More information)
tablePage.totalPage: Returns the total number of pages for this table.
tableRemoveRows.condition: Specifies the expression that determines which rows are removed. For example, to remove the first row in the table, enter row==0. See Scripting and Syntax.
tableRemoveRows.enabled:
Determines whether the block is enabled.

TRUE: The rows are removed when the trigger is invoked.

FALSE: The rows are not removed.
tableRemoveRows.invoke: Causes the rows to be removed.
tableRemoveRows.print: Returns a string that is used for errors, other notifications, and debugging.
tableRemoveRows.table: Receives the input table from which some rows will be removed.
tableRollup.columnFilterType: Specifies whether the column list includes or excludes the specified columns.
tableRollup.dateColumn: Specifies the name of the table column that holds the dates.
tableRollup.input: Receives the table in which you want to roll up values.
tableRollup.interval:
Specifies the duration of the range to roll up. It can be any of the following.
  • One minute
  • Five minutes
  • Ten minutes
  • Fifteen minutes
  • Twenty minutes
  • Thirty minutes
  • Hour
  • Two hours
  • Three hours
  • Four hours
  • Six hours
  • Twelve hours
  • Day
  • Two days
  • Week
  • Month
  • Year
tableRollup.roundTime:
Specifies whether to force all intervals to start at a round number. (More information)

TRUE: Intervals start at a round number. For example, if interval is "day", all intervals start at midnight. If interval is "five minutes", all intervals start at multiples of five minutes past the hour.

FALSE: The first interval starts at the first timestamp, and intervals are appended accordingly. For example, if interval is "day" and the first value is 2015/07/19T08:01:19, then all intervals begin at T08:01:19.
tableRollup.valueColumn: Specifies the name of the table column that holds the values to be rolled up.
tableRollup.valueRollup:
Specifies the type of rollup used.
  • First: Returns the first value for the interval.
  • Last: Returns the last value for the interval.
  • Average: Returns the average of all number values for the interval. Non−number values are treated as null and are not included in the calculation.
  • Sum: Returns the sum of all number values for the interval. If there are no number values, returns 0.
  • Max: Returns the greatest number value from the interval. If there are no number values, returns null.
  • Min: Returns the smallest number value for the interval. Non−number values are treated as null and are not included in the calculation.
  • Count: Returns the number of values that exist for the interval. Null values are not included.
  • Concat: Returns all values for the interval, separated by commas. Duplicate values are included.
  • ConcatUnique: Returns all unique values for the interval, separated by commas. Duplicate values are not included.
tableRowCells.0: Specifies a column name in the input table.
tableRowCells.1: Sets or returns the cell value at the specified row and column n. In addition, updates to the value n property write to the data source if the data source is a Table block. For other data sources, including other block properties that hold the table data type, changing the value does nothing.
tableRowCells.onChange: The event fired when output changes.
tableRowCells.row: Specifies a row index in the input table.
tableRowCells.table: Receives the table from which you want to get values.
tableSelectColumns.columns: Specifies the columns in the input table to select, as comma−separated column names.
tableSelectColumns.input: Receives the table from which you want to select columns.
tableSelectColumns.output: Returns a new table. It contains only the specified columns.
tableSelectRows.indexes: Specifies the rows in the input table to select, as comma−separated values.
tableSelectRows.input: Receives the table from which you want to select rows.
tableSelectRows.output: Returns a new table. It contains only the rows at the specified indexes.
tableSort.field: Specifies the name of the table column to sort by.
tableSort.input: Receives the table that you want to sort.
tableSort.method: Specifies whether to sort values as strings (alphabetically) or as numbers. (More information)
tableSort.order: Specifies whether to sort values in ascending or descending order.
tableTranspose.headerColumn: Specifies the column from the input table to use as headers in the output table.
tableTranspose.headerPrefix: Specifies the text string to include before the column number for each column header in the output table. The headerPrefix property works only when the headerColumn property is null.
tableTranspose.ignoreColumns: Specifies the names of columns in the input table to ignore when transposing, as comma−separated values.
tableTranspose.includeHeaders: Specifies whether the header row from the input table is included as a column in the output table.
tableTranspose.input: Receives the table that you want to transpose.
tan.input: Specifies the angle to get the tangent for, in degrees.
tan.output: Returns the tangent of the input.
target: Specifies the browser window where the content is to be displayed.
text: Sets or reflects the string that appears in this text component.
text.editable: Specifies whether the user can edit the text in this component at runtime by clicking it.
text.ellipsis: Enables or disables display of an ellipsis (...) to indicate content that is too long to display in the field.
text.isAdvancedHTML: Specifies whether the string in this text component is treated as advanced HTML, and all HTML tags are parsed, including hyperlinks.
text.isHTML: Specifies whether the string in this text component is treated as HTML, and HTML tags are parsed. Does not parse advanced HTML tags such as hyperlinks.
text.multiline:
Specifies whether this text component has multiline capability. Hold Alt+Enter to insert a line break.

TRUE: Line breaks are recognized.

FALSE: Line breaks are ignored. All text is displayed on a single line.
text.textSelectable: Specifies whether users can select text in this field.
textAlign: Specifies whether the content in this component is left−justified, centered, or right−justified.
textDecoration: Specifies whether the text in this component is underlined.
textDir: Specifies the direction for text and text input in this component. The Auto option automatically detects the direction as the user enters text.
textEditor.displayAsPassword: Display user-entered text as asterisks rather than clear text.
textFormInput.inputType:
Specifies the valid input type, or the expected input type.
  • Text: A single line of text. Line breaks are automatically removed.
  • Email: A single, properly formatted email address, or the empty string.
  • URL: A single, valid, absolute URL, or the empty string.
  • Tel: A single line of text. Line breaks are automatically removed. On mobile devices, the on−screen keyboard is optimized for number entry.
textFormInput.placeholder: Text displayed in the field to indicate what the user is to enter.
tickLength: Specifies the length of each major tick.
tickPlacement: Specifies whether the major ticks appear on the inside, outside, or center of the line that represents this axis.
tickStroke: Specifies the stroke color of the major ticks.
tickStrokeWidth: Specifies the stroke weight of each major tick.
tilingOpt:
Determines whether the image tiles or scales within its container.
  • No Tiling: The image does not tile. An image larger than its container is clipped.
  • Tiling: The image tiles to fill the container either horizontally, vertically, or both horizontally and vertically.
  • Scaling: The image scales to the size of the container.
tilingOpt.angle: If Repeat Horizontally or Repeat Vertically is selected, changing this value causes tiles to repeat along an angle. Valid values are −45 to 45.
tilingOpt.hAlign:
Determines how images or tiles are horizontally aligned.
  • Left: The leftmost edge of the image or tiles is justified to the left container boundary.
  • Center: The image or tiles are horizontally centered.
  • Right: The rightmost edge of the image or tiles is justified to the right container boundary.
tilingOpt.tiling:
When Tiling is selected, this property determines whether the image tiles horizontally, vertically, or both horizontally and vertically.
  • Repeat: The image tiles horizontally and vertically.
  • Repeat Horizontally: The image tiles horizontally only. One row of tiles appears.
  • Repeat Vertically: The image tiles vertically only. One column of tiles appears.
When Scaling is selected, this property determines how the image scales when its container size changes.
  • Contain: The image scales while maintaining its aspect ratio. Part of the container might be empty.
  • Cover: The image scales to fill the container while maintaining its aspect ratio. Any part of the image that overflows the container is clipped.
  • Stretch: The image stretches to cover the container. The image's aspect ratio is not maintained.
tilingOpt.vAlign:
Determines how images or tiles are vertically aligned.
  • Top: The topmost edge of the image or tiles is justified to the top container boundary.
  • Middle: The image or tiles are vertically centered.
  • Bottom: The bottommost edge of the image or tiles is justified to the bottom container boundary.
timeout: Specifies how long the block attempts to execute data action before the request is canceled.
title: Title
titleBackground: Specifies the fill for the header.
titleBorder: Specifies the stroke color or border image for outlining the header.
titleColor: For internal use, do not change.
titleFontColor: Specifies the font color for the header.
titleFontStyle: Specifies whether the header text is italic.
titleFontWeight: Specifies whether the header text is bold.
titleHeight: Specifies the height of the calendar header, as a pixel value or Auto. A value of Auto means that the height of the header is equal to other calendar cells, and therefore depends on the calendar height.
titleStyle: For internal use, do not change.
titleTextDecoration: For internal use, do not change.
todayBackground: Specifies the fill for the calendar cell that represents the current day, based on the user's date and time settings.
todayBorder: Specifies the stroke color or border image for outlining the calendar cell that represents the current day, based on the user's date and time settings.
todayCornerRadius: Specifies the corner radius for the cell that represents the current day, as arcs of circles or ellipses. The circles or ellipses are defined using a pixel value or percentage. A pixel value is the radius of a circle. A percentage value Specifies an ellipse with horizontal and vertical radii that are that percentage of the cell's width and height, respectively. A value of 0 means that corners are not rounded.
todayFontColor: Specifies the font color for the calendar cell that represents the current day, based on the user's date and time settings.
todayFontFamily:
Specifies the font for the calendar cell that represents the current day. To add a font to your project:
  1. If your project does not have a fonts folder, right−click the root folder for your project, and add a folder named fonts.
  2. Navigate to the font file on your computer and drag it to the fonts folder.
  3. Save your work and refresh the browser.
  4. Specify the font using the drop−down menu for this property.
todayFontSize: Specifies the font size for the calendar cell that represents the current day, based on the user's date and time settings.
todayFontStyle: Specifies whether the text in the today cell is italic.
todayFontWeight: Specifies whether the text in the today cell is bold.
todayStyle: For internal use. Do not change.
toDegree.input: Specifies the angle in radians, to convert to degrees.
toDegree.output: Returns the input value, converted from radians to degrees.
tooltip: Specifies the tooltip text to appear when the user mouses over this component. Tooltips use the default tooltip appearance for the user's browser and operating system. Tooltips appear only when the Mouse Enabled property is TRUE for the component and its parents.
top:
In absolute layout, sets the top edge of this component to a distance above or below the top edge of its parent container.

In vertical or horizontal layout, sets the top edge of this component to a distance above or below its normal position.

Distances are either pixel values, or percentages of the parent height. A value of Auto positions the top edge of this component in its normal position. To set a value of Auto, click the blue dot and select Reset.
topLeftRadius: Specifies the top left rounded corner as an arc of a circle or an ellipse. The circle or ellipse is defined using a pixel value or percentage. A pixel value is the radius of a circle. A percentage value Specifies an ellipse with horizontal and vertical radii that are that percentage of the component's width and height, respectively.
topology.colorField: The table column property that contains the color to be applied to the node.
topology.hSpacing: The amount of horizontal space between nodes, in pixels .
topology.idField: The table column that contains the node ID.
topology.linkColor: The color of the line that connects nodes.
topology.nameField: The table column that contains the node name.
topology.parentField: The table column that contains the parent node of the node described in the row.
topology.textColor: The table column that contains the color to be applied to the node name text.
topology.vSpacing: The amount of vertical space between nodes, in pixels .
topRightRadius: Specifies the top right rounded corner as an arc of a circle or an ellipse. The circle or ellipse is defined using a pixel value or percentage. A pixel value is the radius of a circle. A percentage value Specifies an ellipse with horizontal and vertical radii that are that percentage of the component's width and height, respectively.
toRadian.input: Specifies the angle in degrees, to convert to radians.
toRadian.output: Returns the input value, converted from degrees to radians.
trace.0: Specifies the path to one of the properties that this block monitors.
trace.msg: Specifies a string to be included in the developer console when values for this block are updated.
trace.tracing:
Specifies whether the changes are recorded. To learn about setting the value to Auto, see this page.

TRUE: Changes are logged in the console.

FALSE: Changes are not logged.

Auto: Changes are logged only if the Advanced property **traceLabel** is not null for the Stage.
traceLabel: Label for the trace messages logged by the Trace dataflow block, which monitors changes to specified properties and logs any changes in the browser's JavaScript console. Must be set for stage when tracing value is Auto.
transformOriginX: Specify the X−axis origin for a 3D transform
transformOriginY: Specify the Y−axis origin for a 3D transform
translateX: Specifies a 3D translation using only the value for the X−axis
translateY: Specifies a 3D translation using only the value for the Y−axis
triggerAutoSize: Sets the size of a container to the minimum required to display the components that it contains.
trim.input: Specifies the text to remove whitespace from.
trim.output: Returns the input text, with any leading or trailing whitespace removed.
url: Specifies the location of the asset used by this component. Click the folder icon to select or upload an asset, or enter a relative URL within the project, such as assets/image.png. You can enter any absolute URL, even if its target is outside of your project. You can use any file format that can be rendered by the user's browser.
useClipping: For internal use with SVG decomposition.
useGpu: For debugging a rendering issue with iOS and Safari.
vAlign: Specifies how components in a vertically aligned container are aligned (top, middle or bottom).
value: Sets or returns the current contents of this input component.
valueBinding.0: A data mapping compares a binding's source value to one or more Case values in order, until the statement it is evaluating is TRUE:. For numbers, a data mapping checks whether the source value is less than or equal to the Case value. For other data types, the data mapping checks whether the source value is equal to the Case value. When the first TRUE statement is encountered, that Mapping value is assigned to the binding's target. If none of the statements are TRUE, then the default value is assigned to the binding's target. More complex case mappings can be created in the dataflow using the Case block.
valueBinding.default: A value to assign to the target if none of the expressions are TRUE.
valueBinding.scaleInputMax: The upper bound of the original scale. A scale binding takes the source value's relationship to an original scale and returns the corresponding value on a new scale.
valueBinding.scaleInputMin: The lower bound of the original scale. A scale binding takes the source value's relationship to an original scale and returns the corresponding value on a new scale.
valueBinding.scaleOutputMax: The upper bound of the new scale. A scale binding takes the source value's relationship to an original scale and returns the corresponding value on a new scale.
valueBinding.scaleOutputMin: The lower bound of the new scale. A scale binding takes the source value's relationship to an original scale and returns the corresponding value on a new scale.
valueRollup:
Specifies the type of rollup used.
  • First: Returns the first value for the interval.
  • Last: Returns the last value for the interval.
  • Average: Returns the average of all number values for the interval. Non−number values are treated as null and are not included in the calculation.
  • Sum: Returns the sum of all number values for the interval. If there are no number values, returns 0.
  • Max: Returns the greatest number value from the interval. If there are no number values, returns null.
  • Min: Returns the smallest number value for the interval. Non−number values are treated as null and are not included in the calculation.
  • Count: Returns the number of values that exist for the interval. Null values are not included.
  • Concat: Returns all values for the interval, separated by commas. Duplicate values are included.
  • ConcatUnique: Returns all unique values for the interval, separated by commas. Duplicate values are not included.
variance.0: Specifies one of the numbers in the set.
variance.output: Returns the variance of the input values.
vCenter:
In absolute or horizontal layout, sets the vertical center of this component to a distance above or below the vertical center of its parent container. The value can be pixels, or a percent of the parent height.

A negative value moves this component up, and a positive value moves it down. A value of Auto positions the vertical center of this component in its normal position in the layout. To set a value of Auto, click the blue dot and select Reset.
verticalAlign: Specifies whether the content in this component is positioned at the top, middle, or bottom of the container.
verticalAxisTitleAlignment: Controls axis title orientation for a vertical axis. Orientation can be either Vertical or Flipped Vertical. You might want to select Vertical if the axis is on the left of the chart, and Flipped Vertical if the axis is on the right.
vGap: Specifies the minimum number of pixels between components in a vertical layout, or between columns in a wrapped horizontal layout. When Vertical Alignment is Flex−Start, Vertical Gap Specifies a bottom padding, but you must define a top padding separately. For all other Vertical Alignments, Vertical Gap specifies a top padding, but you must define a bottom padding separately.
video.@onEnded: Triggers an event on completion of this video. Can be used to invoke actions.
video.autoplay: Specifies whether the video starts playing automatically when the video player component is loaded on the page.
video.controls: Specifies whether video controls are shown to the user.
video.pause: Pauses the video. You can bind to this button, or click it as part of a recorded action.
video.play: Plays the video. You can bind to this button, or click it as part of a recorded action.
video.restart: Restarts the video. You can bind to this button, or click it as part of a recorded action.
video.stop: Stops the video. You can bind to this button, or click it as part of a recorded action.
video.url: Specifies the path where the video is located. Click the folder icon to select or upload an image, or enter a relative URL within the project, such as assets/video.mp4. You can also enter any absolute URL, even if it is outside of your project. You can use any video format that is supported by the user's browser.
video.volume: Changes the video player's volume. You can bind to this property, or modify it as part of a recorded action.
viewDeck.symbol: Specifies the symbol to be used when iterating the rows of the linked table. If the symbol is defined in this project, enter the name of the symbol. To use a symbol from another project in your library, enter the path to that symbol.
virtualLayout: Enables virtual layout for a group repeater.
visibility:
Specifies whether this component is visible. Regardless of value, the component affects layout and is stored in the user's browser memory. Because the component is stored in memory, performance might be affected.

TRUE: This component is visible.

FALSE: This component is not visible, but it still affects layout and is stored in browser memory.
vScroll:
Specifies vertical scrolling behavior on this component.
  • Off: Vertical scrolling is always disabled.
  • On: Vertical scrolling is always enabled. The track appears even if the content does not overflow.
  • Auto: Vertical scrolling is automatically enabled when content overflows.
vZoomMax: Sets or returns the maximum of the range on the vertical axis for the zoomed view. If either Minimum or Maximum is null, the zoom does not happen. Zooming works only with linear, log, and datetime axes. For dates, use the format "yyyyMMdd".
vZoomMin: Sets or returns the minimum of the range on the vertical axis for the zoomed view. If either Minimum or Maximum is null, the zoom does not happen. Zooming works only with linear, log, and datetime axes. For dates, use the format "yyyyMMdd".
vZoomTrigger: Zooms the chart to the range specified by the Vertical Zoom Minimum and Maximum. To return the chart to its pre−zoom view, the user can click on the chart. Zooming works only with linear, log, and datetime axes.
webDocument.@onAfterPrint: Fires after the browser window contents are sent to the printer dialog. You can use this for reverting changes made using onBeforePrint.
webDocument.@onBeforePrint: Fires before the browser window contents are sent to the printer dialog. You can use this for changing configuration to prepare for printing.
webDocument.appCodeName: Retrieves the internal code name of the browser. However, it is not a reliable source of information and returns "Mozilla" in most cases.
webDocument.appName: Retrieves the name of the user's browser. However, it is not a reliable source of information and often returns "Netscape" for various browsers.
webDocument.appVersion: Retrieves the browser version. It might not be accurate.
webDocument.hash: Sets or returns the string to appear after the hash (#) symbol in the URL. This allows you to create deep links and custom experiences based on data, properties, or user interaction. The hash value is saved across sessions and browser windows. The browser's Back and Forward commands iterate through hash addresses.
webDocument.hasTouch: Returns whether the user's device has a touch screen.
webDocument.height: Retrieves the height of the usable portion of the user's browser window in pixels.
webDocument.host: Returns the path to the host of this project.
webDocument.inIFrame: Returns whether this instance of the project is within an IFrame.
webDocument.initialScale:
Determines the zoom level at which the project is opened. Only applies to mobile devices.

A value of 1: The application appears at normal scale.

Values greater than 1: The application appears smaller on mobile devices.
